There is also the question if these distance terms are demonstratives, because they hve to be nominalized before they can be used in the "classcal" function of demonstratives, modifing NPs. 
How to define a demonstrative?

Directionals (Nagaya's term for geocentric terms referring to directions) can be used as demonstratives. There are two directionals encoding elevation. However, it is not obligatory to use them, one can also use demonstratives that only encode distnce or horizontal direction.

different possessive morphology applys for alienable and inalienable relationships

1. two word order patterns
Nominal possessors precede the noun.
Pronominal possessors follow the noun.
2. two different morphological markings 
Possessors can be expressed through suffixes/enclitics on the noun (with optional nominal possessor). In this case alienability decides if the affix or the enclitic is used.
Suffix on the possessed noun for inalienable possession, enclitic for alienable possession.
Suffix on possessed noun for inalienable possession, enclitic for alienable possession.
possessor noun prenominal, possessor pronoun postnominal
Adjectival verbs don't take verbal agreement.
Adjectival verb need to be nominalized in attributive position, in the same way verbs do.
Certain verbs, all adverbial demonstratives and adverbial directionals can function as prepositions. These are the only native prepositions.
Locative nouns might be on the way of developing into postpositions.
Recipient/beneficary arguments can optionally be marked with adposition but then change their position and to appear as oblique.
Oblique NPs can be marked by deverbal ('give' for beneficary) or deadverbal prepositions ('here' for recipient) .
This information is expressed in caluse-final deictic motion verbs GO and COME.

Comment:
Labial, Alveolar, Velar and Glottal
Nagaya gives 6 places, I however would reduced the phonemic places of articulation to 4. The dental place of articulation does exist in the phonetic articulation, however I do not consider it to be phonemic because it only appear for one consonant (/t/) and it is not relvant to produce a phonemic constrast. The same holds for the alveo-palatal place of articulation (for /dʒ/). In this case, the phonetic articulation is reported to be alveo-palatal but I could imaging that it migth also be articulated alveolarly, as this is for example the case in neighbouring Hewa.
There are not clusters of a nasal followed by a velar stop.
nasal vowels; however, phonemic status questionable
ə ɐ
penultimate stress
only glottal stop is allowed word-finally
